title: After loss to Warren, Republican John Deaton announces another run for Senate
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: John Deaton announces candidacy for Sen. Ed Markey’s seat after losing to Sen. Elizabeth Warren.
Deaton, a Marine veteran and lawyer, highlights his youth and work background as part of his campaign.
Markey faces a primary challenge from Seth Moulton, with Ayanna Pressley considering joining the race.

title: What will the Red Sox target this offseason? Craig Breslow maps out Boston’s priorities.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox aim to acquire a top starting pitcher to pair with ace Garrett Crochet for stronger postseason prospects.
Boston is exploring trades and free agency for elite pitchers and power hitters to enhance their roster.
Beyond pitching, the Red Sox seek to add more power to their lineup, considering sluggers like Kyle Schwarber and Pete Alonso.

title: Zdeno Chara’s 10 most memorable moments with the Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Zdeno Chara served as Boston Bruins captain for 14 years, winning a Stanley Cup and creating a lasting team culture.
Chara was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, celebrated for his impactful career as one of NHL's top defensemen.
Chara's career highlights include setting the NHL hardest shot record and playing in the 2019 Stanley Cup Final with a broken jaw.

title: Bill Belichick reflects on ‘learning curve’ during first season coaching college football
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Bill Belichick is in his first season coaching North Carolina, with a current record of 4-5 in ACC play.
Belichick cited a 'learning curve' in adapting NFL strategies to college football's unique challenges at UNC.
North Carolina needs two wins in their last three games to match last season's total and become bowl eligible.

title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots report includes 15 injured players ahead of Thursday's game against the Jets, following Sunday's win over the Buccaneers.
Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson were limited in practice after missing the Buccaneers game due to hamstring and toe injuries.
Tight end Austin Hooper did not participate Monday due to a concussion as Patriots prepare for a short-week matchup.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, 44, of Atlanta, accused of stealing millions in unclaimed Massachusetts property using fraudulent claims.
Stayman allegedly cashed $1.1 million in checks and attempted to claim $2.2 million more by impersonating claimants.
Stayman held on $2 million bail while facing 25 counts; court alleges use of fake documents and identities.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson looked to the sideline for guidance on whether to score or run down the clock during a key play.
In the final quarter, Henderson scored a touchdown despite mixed signals from the sideline, sealing a productive day.
With Rhamondre Stevenson out, Henderson has taken on a larger role, highlighted by his first 100-yard, multi-touchdown game.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei returned to the Bruins lineup after being benched for five games, aiding a win over Toronto with two assists.
Head coach Marco Sturm benched Lohrei due to defensive struggles, but he responded positively in his comeback game.
Lohrei's performance is part of a trend where Bruins players bounce back strongly from lineup challenges under Sturm.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Signature gatherers accused of misleading voters on proposed ballot to repeal recreational marijuana in Massachusetts.
Complaints filed with Secretary of the Commonwealth regarding deceptive practices in signature collection.
Cannabis advocate calls actions 'organized voter fraud' as accusations surface against petitioners.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, marking a decrease from $10.26 billion in 2024.
UMass employees dominate top salaries, with Frank Martin earning $1.95 million as the highest-paid state employee.
UMass system accounted for $1.55 billion of state payroll, leading over MBTA and Trial Court expenditures.
